case_id: Social Action Forum for Manav Adhikar v. Union of India (2018) 10 SCC 443
facts: Writ Petition (Civil) No. 73 of 2015 filed by Social Action Forum for Manav Adhikar and another under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.
The petition challenged the perceived dilution and potential undermining of Section 498A IPC due to directions issued by the Supreme Court in Rajesh Sharma v. State of U.P. (2018) 10 SCC 472.
The Rajesh Sharma judgment (July 27, 2017) issued several directions aimed at preventing the alleged misuse of Section 498A.

Key directions in Rajesh Sharma included: Establishment of Family Welfare Committees (FWCs) in each district; complaints under Section 498A to be referred to the FWC before further action/arrest; interaction with the accused/complainant by the FWC; report submission by FWC to the Magistrate; restrictions on arrest (generally no arrest before FWC report, especially of outstation relatives/elderly); provision for personal appearance exemption for accused; clubbing of cases.
Petitioners argued these directions were effectively creating new procedures not envisaged by the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) or the IPC, thereby obstructing justice for victims of cruelty.
The petitioners sought modification/recall of the directions issued in Rajesh Sharma.
The Supreme Court, in this case (Social Action Forum), reviewed the directions issued in Rajesh Sharma.

The Court heard arguments regarding the legislative intent behind Section 498A, the documented misuse of the provision, and the applicability of existing safeguards under the CrPC (like Section 41 and 41A).
The judgment was delivered on September 14, 2018 by a three-judge bench comprising Chief Justice Dipak Misra, Justice A.M. Khanwilkar, and Justice D.Y. Chandrachud.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The directions in Rajesh Sharma v. State of U.P. effectively dilute Section 498A IPC and create extra-judicial mechanisms (Family Welfare Committees) not sanctioned by law, hindering the effective prosecution of cruelty against women.
precedents: Lalita Kumari v. Govt. of U.P. (2014) 2 SCC 1 (Mandatory registration of FIR for cognizable offences)
State of Karnataka v. L. Muniswamy (1977) 2 SCC 699 (Inherent power cannot be used against express bar of law)
State of Punjab v. Davinder Pal Singh Bhullar (2011) 14 SCC 770 (Courts cannot create parallel forums or procedures)
elements: Legislative intent of Section 498A (to protect women from cruelty)
Supremacy of statutory procedure (CrPC) over judicial directions
Potential for FWCs to impede investigation and delay justice

counter_arguments.loophole: Acknowledged widespread misuse of Section 498A, necessitating safeguards to protect innocent family members from arbitrary arrest and harassment.
supporting_precedents: Rajesh Sharma v. State of U.P. (2018) 10 SCC 472 (Rationale for the guidelines based on misuse)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Observed tendency to implicate all relatives)
Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273 (Acknowledged misuse and laid down arrest guidelines for offences punishable up to 7 years)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The mandatory referral to FWCs and the bar on immediate arrest (before FWC report) contradicts CrPC provisions, particularly regarding police investigation powers and arrest procedures for cognizable offences.
precedents: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273 (Provides sufficient guidelines for arrest under S. 41/41A CrPC, making FWC redundant for this purpose)
H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi AIR 1955 SC 196 (Emphasizes stages of investigation under CrPC)
Union of India v. Prakash P. Hinduja (2003) 6 SCC 195 (Judiciary cannot interfere with investigation process)
elements: Police powers under Chapter XII CrPC (Information to Police and Powers to Investigate)
Arrest procedures under Section 41 and 41A CrPC
Judicial non-interference in statutory investigation process

counter_arguments.loophole: The guidelines aimed to introduce a 'cooling-off' period and preliminary verification to prevent impulsive arrests based on potentially false or exaggerated allegations, serving the interest of justice.
supporting_precedents: Joginder Kumar v. State of U.P. (1994) 4 SCC 260 (Arrest should not be routine; need for justification)
Sushil Kumar Sharma v. Union of India (2005) 6 SCC 281 (Acknowledged misuse; termed it 'legal terrorism')
Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Cautioned against implicating relatives without specific allegations)

defense_arguments.argument: The directions in Rajesh Sharma were a necessary judicial response to the documented and rampant misuse of Section 498A, intended to balance the protection of victims with the rights of the accused and their families.
edge_cases: Difficulty in distinguishing genuine from false complaints at the initial stage.
Impact of immediate arrest on reputation, job, and family life of potentially innocent individuals.
precedents: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273 (Emphasized need for police satisfaction and checklist before arrest in 498A cases)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Highlighted misuse for oblique motives)
Savitri Devi v. Ramesh Chand (2003) ILR 1 Delhi 419 (Delhi HC observations on misuse)

defense_arguments.argument: The existing CrPC safeguards, particularly Section 41 and 41A, as interpreted in Arnesh Kumar, provide an adequate framework to prevent unnecessary arrests, and the Rajesh Sharma directions were an attempt to operationalize these principles.
edge_cases: Ensuring consistent application of Section 41A notice procedure by police across jurisdictions.
Providing a mechanism (like FWC) for preliminary assessment before formal police action.
precedents: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273 (Mandatory procedures before arrest for offences up to 7 years)
Joginder Kumar v. State of U.P. (1994) 4 SCC 260 (Right to life and liberty; arrest is a serious matter)
D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal (1997) 1 SCC 416 (General guidelines regarding arrest and detention)

judgment.outcome: Directions issued in Rajesh Sharma v. State of U.P. were modified/recalled. Specifically, the directions pertaining to the establishment and functioning of Family Welfare Committees (FWCs) and the bar on arrest pending FWC report were set aside.
reasoning: The constitution of FWCs and referral of complaints to them before police action is not contemplated under the CrPC and amounts to creating a parallel mechanism outside the statutory framework.
Directions preventing immediate arrest pending FWC report are impermissible and dilute the effectiveness of the cognizable offence defined under Section 498A.
The legislature has enacted the law (Section 498A) and the procedure (CrPC), and the judiciary cannot create new procedures or forums through judicial directives that run contrary to the statute.

The guidelines laid down in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding arrest procedures under Sections 41 and 41A CrPC are comprehensive and must be strictly followed by police authorities. These provide adequate safeguards against arbitrary arrest.

While acknowledging the potential misuse of Section 498A, the Court held that such misuse cannot be grounds for diluting the provision itself or creating extra-legal procedures. Remedies lie in enforcing existing safeguards (Arnesh Kumar guidelines) and potentially through legislative change if deemed necessary.
Directions regarding exemption from personal appearance and clubbing of cases were retained as being procedural and within judicial discretion.
The Court emphasized adherence to the procedures outlined in CrPC and the principles established in Lalita Kumari and Arnesh Kumar.
